# Introduction to Algorithms

Welcome to **Algorithms** - step-by-step problem solving!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Algorithm Basics** - What they are and why they matter
- **Complexity Analysis** - Big O notation
- **Sorting** - Organizing data
- **Searching** - Finding data
- **Algorithm Design** - Strategies

> **Fun Fact:** The word 'algorithm' comes from the Persian mathematician al-Khwarizmi!

slides.title: Algorithm Basics
slides.content:
# Algorithm Basics

## Definition:
A finite set of well-defined instructions to solve a problem.

## Properties:
- **Input:** Zero or more inputs
- **Output:** At least one output
- **Definiteness:** Clear, unambiguous steps
- **Finiteness:** Terminates after finite steps
- **Effectiveness:** Each step is basic and doable

## Representation:
- Natural language
- Pseudocode
- Flowcharts
- Programming code

## Example (Finding Maximum):
```
1. Set max = first element
2. For each remaining element:
   a. If element > max, set max = element
3. Return max
```

slides.title: Complexity Analysis
slides.content:
# Complexity Analysis

## Big O Notation:
Describes how runtime grows with input size.

| Notation | Name | Example |
|----------|------|--------|
| O(1) | Constant | Array access |
| O(log n) | Logarithmic | Binary search |
| O(n) | Linear | Linear search |
| O(n log n) | Linearithmic | Merge sort |
| O(n^2) | Quadratic | Bubble sort |
| O(2^n) | Exponential | Fibonacci recursive |
| O(n!) | Factorial | Permutations |

## Rules:
- Drop constants: O(2n) = O(n)
- Drop lower terms: O(n^2 + n) = O(n^2)
- Worst case usually considered

## Space Complexity:
- Memory used by algorithm
- Also measured in Big O

slides.title: Sorting Algorithms
slides.content:
# Sorting Algorithms

## Comparison:

| Algorithm | Best | Average | Worst | Space |
|-----------|------|---------|-------|-------|
| Bubble | O(n) | O(n^2) | O(n^2) | O(1) |
| Selection | O(n^2) | O(n^2) | O(n^2) | O(1) |
| Insertion | O(n) | O(n^2) | O(n^2) | O(1) |
| Merge | O(n log n) | O(n log n) | O(n log n) | O(n) |
| Quick | O(n log n) | O(n log n) | O(n^2) | O(log n) |
| Heap | O(n log n) | O(n log n) | O(n log n) | O(1) |

## Bubble Sort:
- Compare adjacent, swap if wrong order
- Repeat until sorted

## Merge Sort:
- Divide array in half
- Sort each half recursively
- Merge sorted halves

## Quick Sort:
- Choose pivot
- Partition around pivot
- Sort partitions recursively

slides.title: Searching Algorithms
slides.content:
# Searching Algorithms

## Linear Search:
- Check each element in order
- O(n) time
- Works on unsorted data

```
for i = 0 to n-1:
    if array[i] == target:
        return i
return not found
```

## Binary Search:
- Requires sorted data
- O(log n) time
- Divide and conquer

```
low = 0, high = n-1
while low <= high:
    mid = (low + high) / 2
    if array[mid] == target:
        return mid
    else if array[mid] < target:
        low = mid + 1
    else:
        high = mid - 1
return not found
```

## Hash Table Lookup:
- O(1) average time
- Uses hash function

slides.title: Algorithm Design Strategies
slides.content:
# Algorithm Design Strategies

## Brute Force:
- Try all possibilities
- Simple but often slow

## Divide and Conquer:
- Break into subproblems
- Solve recursively
- Combine solutions
- Examples: Merge sort, binary search

## Greedy:
- Make locally optimal choice
- Hope for global optimum
- Examples: Dijkstra's, Huffman coding

## Dynamic Programming:
- Break into overlapping subproblems
- Store solutions (memoization)
- Build up solution
- Examples: Fibonacci, shortest paths

## Backtracking:
- Explore possibilities
- Abandon bad paths early
- Examples: N-queens, Sudoku

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Algorithms Summary

## Big O Hierarchy:
O(1) < O(log n) < O(n) < O(n log n) < O(n^2) < O(2^n)

## Sorting:
| Algorithm | Time | When to Use |
|-----------|------|-------------|
| Quick Sort | O(n log n) avg | General purpose |
| Merge Sort | O(n log n) | Stable, guaranteed |
| Insertion | O(n^2) | Small/nearly sorted |

## Searching:
- Linear: O(n), any data
- Binary: O(log n), sorted data

## Design Strategies:
- Divide and conquer
- Greedy
- Dynamic programming
- Backtracking
